title: Stanford coach David Shaw says it's time for a rest
text:
Posted: 10/06/2015 02:22:00 PM PDT Updated: 10/06/2015 02:34:10 PM PDT College Hotline blog STANFORD -- His offense has found a groove not seen around these parts in years, but Stanford coach David Shaw prefers rest to rhythm. 
"It's coming at a great time for us,'' Shaw said of this week's bye, which leads into the Oct. 15 showdown against UCLA. 
Shaw then rattled off a list of players who would be hobbled if the No. 16 Cardinal, which has scored more than 40 points in three consecutive games, were playing Saturday. 
That list consisted of quarterback Kevin Hogan and most of the defensive line. 
Two starters, Aziz Shittu and Brennan Scarlett, and the top backup, Nate Lohn, are hobbling. Stanford (4-1, 3-0) has already lost starter Harrison Phillips for the year and has used a makeshift line for stretches of the past three games. Stanford's David Shaw enters the field with the team before playing Central Florida at Stanford Stadium in Stanford, Calif., on Saturday, Sept. 12, 2015. (Jim Gensheimer/Bay Area News Group) ( Jim Gensheimer ) 
Meanwhile, Hogan still hasn't recovered from the sprained left ankle suffered in the third quarter at USC. Then again, it hasn't affected his play: In the two games since the injury, he has a 78.7 completion percentage. 
"I've teased him that we should have kicked him in the ankle early last year,'' Shaw said. "(But) he's been that way before the ankle. He has calm about him. All the ankle has done is slowed him down a little as a runner. But as far as pocket mechanics, he's been outstanding." 
Redshirt freshman Keller Chryst replaced Hogan in the late stages of the blowout victory over Arizona, but that doesn't necessarily mean he's the No. 2 quarterback, ahead of sophomore Ryan Burns. 
"It's fluid,'' Shaw said. 
Chryst is ahead of Burns -- and every other offensive player â€” in one category: Pancake blocks. 
He flattened Arizona cornerback Cam Denson on Christian McCaffrey's 25-yard run in the second quarter. 
"We all thought that was the funniest thing ever, slash, felt really bad for that guy,'' Stanford linebacker Blake Martinez said, "because he should never play football.'' 
Chryst weighs 233 pounds. Denson is all of 168. 
Turnovers remain a source of concern for Shaw -- not the frequency of giveaways, but the paucity of takeaways. 
Stanford has committed four turnovers in five games (tied for 16th nationally), but it has forced only three (120th). 
"Sometimes, it's the way the ball bounces, but we're going to keep working on it,'' Shaw said. "We need turnover plays. Those things have eluded us -- the things you need to have to take pressure off the offense for driving 60, 70, 80 yards at a time." 
Outside linebacker Kevin Anderson (undisclosed) is not expected to play next week. For more on college sports, see Jon Wilner's College Hotline at blogs.mercurynews.com/collegesports . Contact him at jwilner@mercurynews.com or 408-920-5716.
